answeringCalls: Let unknown calls go to voicemail
Hang up if pressured or threatened
protectingYourself: Register on National Do Not Call Registry
Never give personal information over phone
reportingScams: Contact your bank if financial information was shared
Place fraud alert with credit bureaus

impersonationScams.description: Scammers pretend to be from legitimate organizations such as utility companies, banks, or government agencies to obtain personal information or money.
examples: Calls from someone claiming to be from Ameren Missouri demanding immediate payment or face disconnection.
Emails purporting to be from the IRS requesting personal information for a tax refund.

robocalls.description: Automated phone calls that often deliver pre-recorded messages promoting scams or trying to gather personal information.
examples: Calls offering free vacations or prizes in exchange for personal details.
Calls from fake debt collectors attempting to collect on non-existent debts.

techSupportScams.description: Scammers offer unsolicited technical support for computer problems and charge excessive fees for unnecessary services.
examples: Pop-up ads claiming the computer is infected with viruses and providing a phone number to call for assistance.
Calls from individuals claiming to be from Microsoft offering to fix computer issues.

grandparentScams.description: Scammers call elderly individuals pretending to be a grandchild in distress and requesting money for bail or other emergencies.
examples: Calls from someone claiming to be a grandchild arrested in a foreign country and needing money for bail.
Calls from someone posing as a lawyer or bail bondsman asking for money to release a grandchild from jail.

general: Be cautious of unsolicited phone calls, emails, or texts asking for personal information or money.
Never share personal information such as Social Security numbers, bank account numbers, or passwords over the phone or through email.
Verify the identity of callers or senders by calling back known phone numbers or visiting official websites.
Use caution when clicking on links or opening attachments in emails or text messages.
Be aware of common scam patterns and educate yourself about how to protect your information.
specificToArea: Be aware of the impersonation scam involving Ameren Missouri. Scammers may call and demand immediate payment or threaten disconnection. Always contact Ameren Missouri directly at (314) 556-2000 to verify any suspicious calls.
Report robocalls to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) at 1-888-382-1222 or online at https://reportfraud.ftc.gov/#/.
If you are targeted by a tech support scam, hang up immediately and contact a reputable computer repair company.
Warn elderly family members about grandparent scams and advise them to never send money without verifying the identity of the caller.
